content:
Python assignment is more flexible than “name = value”. The language reference describes different assignment target forms and their behavior.

---
## 1) One value to multiple names

```python
x = y = z = 0
print(x, y, z)  # 0 0 0
```python

---
## 2) Unpacking assignment (tuple/list)

```python
point = (10, 20)
x, y = point
print(x, y)      # 10 20

rgb = [255, 128, 0]
r, g, b = rgb
print(r, g, b)
```python

Common error case:

```python
# a, b = (1, 2, 3)  # ValueError: too many values to unpack
```python

---
## 3) Assignment targets are not only names
You can assign to:
- names
- attributes (`obj.attr`)
- items (`obj[index]` or `obj[key]`)

### Attribute assignment

```python
class Box:
    pass

b = Box()
b.value = 99
print(b.value)
```python

### Item assignment (list/dict)

```python
nums = [1, 2, 3]
nums[0] = 100
print(nums)  # [100, 2, 3]

m = {"count": 1}
m["count"] = m["count"] + 1
print(m)     # {'count': 2}
```python

---
## 4) A compact “many forms” practice block

```python
x = 1
x = x + 1

(a, b) = (10, 20)

nums = [0, 1, 2]
nums[2] = 99

class C:
    pass
obj = C()
obj.name = "Ada"

print(x, a, b)
print(nums)
print(obj.name)
```
title: Assignment basics beyond '=': multiple targets, unpacking, and what can be assigned to
